comments.commentBody: My experience at 24 hr. VCA clinics supports the report you cite. I found the doctors were almost always in favor of doing a lot of tests even though they were not always necessary. They were also considerably more expensive than my regular vet. I made it a practice of doing only what was necessary and following up with my vet for any further testing.
All women are at risk. You're not Ivanka who can, according to her dad, "Just go work somewhere else."

I cannot participate in the march because I'm out of the country but I would not if I could. I am part of a Facebook group for supporters of Hillary. For a long time I found many posts inane or irritating: they were often by women who exaggerated some trivial everyday slight into a momentous political event and then solicited virtual hugs and support from total strangers. But I gave up on that "movement" when a black woman wrote a post castigating everybody white and demanding "informed listening" instead of daring to voice their opinions. Sorry I won't be shamed into keeping my mouth shut just because of the color of your skin. I get it that it's hard to be a black woman in the US. I was born a Jew in the USSR. Care to know what happened to my grandparents? And if you don't, why should I care to know what happened to your slave ancestors? I've known many women who suffered unimaginable hardships: a Chinese whose parents starved to death in Mao's famine; an Arab in Israel who has to fight both the conservatism of her own community and the discrimination by the Jewish majority; a Ukrainian who cleans other people's houses because she lost everything she had in Putin's war. None of them whined, tried to shut up others or declined well-meaning help from people who were luckier than they.

My thoughts exactly. She never saw her father marched off to war at gun point never to return, run for cover when Russians came through, praying they did not get raped, lived through the bombing and firestorm in Dresden and so many other atrocities. To judge others based on their whiteness is the same as judging others on their blackness, that is racism. To say where whites are there is racism, is a racist remark itself. Thanks but no thanks, I can't and won't work with racist people.

And you know what? I have no such family tragedies in my background and my opinion STILL counts. I don't think we need to have a contest of "who's had the most pain?" I am against Trump. I believe that he and Pence are dangerous for women, minorities, LGBTQs, the poor, the environment, and the planet. I am an ally, despite my white skin.

Telling me to "check my privilege" and trying to bring the focus onto only one subsection of harm this administration can do is a waste of effort. It reminds me of those who complained, "How can you be so upset about Cecil (or Harambe) being shot when there are children who are starving?" ... as if one can only be concerned about one issue at a time.

And no, I won't be drowning myself in anyone's poetry. I don't particularly care for modern poetry. I also don't like salsa dancing, but that doesn't mean I'm anti-Latino.

Sarah,

This article is, in part, about black women not being heard. You only mention black men and white women in your comment.

Many of these comments, imploring black women to see the larger picture and not worry about race right now, sound eerily like the 1970s feminist movement and unintentional alienation of women of color by white spokeswomen and participants.

If you see Gloria Steinem, ask what she thinks of Shirley Chisholm now.

The left and the right both have their extremes.  Yes, even the liberals.  Dont let a few small divisive voices get amplified to a point of non-action.  Stay engaged. More than 50% of this country will probably agree that Trump is unfit, period.  That's what this is about.

Todd,
I was a young woman in the 1970's when I decided to enter the practice of law. Every word you say is true. Amen. And thank you for speaking out.

He is speaking to the doors that were open to him because he was a white man. If you were to walk around this world with black skin you would know the invisible privilege you have over others. As a white woman I definitely have privilege that people of color do not. Very hard to see. It too a lot of effort on my part to see it. Reading. Listening.   In the end- if the doors are open to all - we all win.

We white women are not being honest with ourselves if we don't acknowledge that we benefit from "white privilege"  and not one of us really knows how it feels to be a person of color in the US.  The Brooklyn activist's post might not have been "diplomatic" but listening more and talking less is good advice.
We all have something to contribute. I will not be silenced.
Being asked to listen more is not the same as being silenced.
Why can't we all just get along?
comments.userDisplayName: Living in liberal la la land

comments.commentBody: Actually, Donald Trump has always been pro-abortion. What are you talking about?

Ummm.. I work,as do the women I'm traveling with. We will work Friday,  be on a bus all Friday night, marching, and home again Sunday around 3 in the morning. So we can go to work on Monday.  Don't assume.

Congratulations on your child raising. Success in the workplace is not enough. Women's rights and human rights and we can see that prior progress can be quickly dismantled. I wish you and your daughter both would join women everywhere and march to show we have a powerful voice.

What, has this event been hacked by Russians, too? Women, and men, just go to the March and contribute your energy as a concerned, patriotic American! Let's come together without all this angst about what it should be. Why should someone's interpretation of what it is bother you? Let it be what it's going to be. The fabric of great coming-togethers are created from many threads.

Well you do have a point. I find the purity dimension of the left baffling.

But the downside is gutting your supposed "conservative" beliefs to win and realize that your have enabled a guy just this side of a fascist without any of the religious hoo-ha that you say you believe in. You end up with evangelists supporting a guy who has assaulted women, hard right religious who put a guy who went to court and settled for Fraud. I guess their denial skills helps but no one believes a word they say.
I and every one of my white women friends voted for Clinton.  I accept no responsibility for trumps win.

Is this question for real? This march is for ALL men and women who are sickened by the real possibility that women's rights will take a dive under this administration. The signs are already there. Join us.

Can you read?  I suspect not.  People did not leave the Democratic Party in droves as you claim.  And, by the way, how many people equal a drove.  Obviously you are a Trump supporter since you have the same ability to lie without shame.
Just Show Up. And bring your daughter.
People wanting to divide people by sex are surprised when they are divided out by race.  Only in la la land.

I feel offended by people who think that there is something great about denying one's own personal desires, or that if one is getting some personal fulfillment out of doing something generous then it makes it frivolous or selfish. I am grateful that people are spending their hard earned money and vacation time on something important for me personally. I personally would much rather be on the beach than out in the cold walking with a crowd of people. I will make it fun and pleasant and friendly! I believe that goodness can be pleasant.
No it is not concrete, nor is anything that Trump has said his entire campaign except when he said things like that he planned on building a wall on the Mexican border, which is very concrete. Not everything built and made of concrete is useful, and having schools built is not important if our freedoms are taken away from us. In fact most of the USA is built on the basis of a piece of paper. The groundwork for that school is not solid.
I personally buy as many things as I can that are made in America rather than imports, I very much agree with that value. American freedoms are priceless and I am marching for that very unconcrete value, worth every penny. Going to a march is respectable. Better than sitting home and letting Trump and his cronies think I don't care about my America.

and Elke
Did not have to CHEW too hard on this; do like word ladders.
Took nine moves to get from BLACK to WHITE , but noticed the GENTLEMEN separated only by one square from LOCOS. A case of OCCAM's razor ?
One hiccup : tried very hard for 19D to fit in LO(c)O(s) or "lavatory" . TSK- IT'S ME and my "cheerfulness".

Another reference to the game and its history and rules can be found at :
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reversi
Had fun with this.

True, Republicans promoted bad policy (deficit reduction during high unemployment).

But Obama did not fight them. Instead (in Feb 2010), *Obama* (not Republicans) - led the charge to cut spending, with his executive order creating the commission to cut the deficit, and appointing Simpson and Bowles to head the commission (both known to be in favor of cutting Social Security and Medicare).

http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/81863-obama-names-simpson-and...

Everyone knew all along that government spending to build bridges, roads, trains would have created much needed jobs. No fancy IS/LM required. But BO bailed out bankers with TARP and QE - and gave little stimulus and little loan relief for homeowners. No wonder Dems suffered huge losses in Nov 2010.

Deficit scaring was just an excuse for a "grand bargain" - supported by the elites in both parties, and opposed by the voters of both parties - to cut SS.

Now, Trump is finally doing what Obama should have done all along: Use the bully pulpit to twist arms for needed stimulus.

And PK is wrong about being at full employment: U6 is still high. Low productivity positions can be vacated. Efficiency gains will free up labor for high productivity infrastructure jobs. Much untapped supply potential exists - due to years of cheap excess labor reducing incentives for efficiency. Look at Japan: repeated rounds of stimulus, very low U3 - and *still* low inflation.

A boy named Sue (Johnny Cash). Now we have a girl named Bob.

“Women’s March on Washington Opens Contentious Dialogue About Race.” Subtitled, All Victims Are Equal But Some Are More Equal Than Others (George Orwell), or Step Up and Watch the Victims Outvictiming Each Other (Anonymous Carnival Barker).

To Jennifer Willis, re “white privilege,” how could you have missed Nicholas Kristof’s six part New York Times series, “What Whites Just Don’t Get” or Michael Eric Tyson in this past Sunday’s New York Times Magazine. For starters, look up the definition of guilt trip. And make sure, on “police brutality,” you don’t mention the black female police officer who was killed today in Orlando or the many other police officers, male and female, black, white and of other races, killed in the line of duty. Be particularly careful not to describe Ferguson as the hoax it was.

We were treated this past presidential election to Hillary Clinton’s “deplorables.” The march this Saturday, I have no doubt, will ultimately coalesce around that theme, with no epithet too low to be beneath the march’s description of the ultimate deplorable, now the president-elect, by Saturday the president.

Not at all.  When they go low, we go high.  I promise that I, personally, will challenge anyone whom I hear making ad hominem attacks on the sitting President during the March. We don't need to call him names to make our point.

To back down from something as memorable and empowering as this March b/c she felt threatened by one comment on Facebook! What a sad way to set an example for young girls. Shame on you Ms. Willis. Stay safe in your little circle where everyone agrees with you.

The oldest trick of those in power--split natural allies. Power is then retained. We have only ourselves to blame.

Poor white women share far more with poor women of color than they do with middle and upper class women, including lack of access to heathcare, low wages, higher rates of sexual assault . . . I could go on. Women of color, too, are not a monolithic group. Those who are citizens have privilege over those who are undocumented, those who speak English over those who don't, and those with educations over those without. Intersectionality means more than the meeting of race and gender.
